subject: Public Speaking
title: Reappraisal: Anxiety as Excitement
description: One-minute skill: Reappraisal: Anxiety as Excitement.

hook.text: Harvard researcher Alison Wood Brooks found something counterintuitive: saying 'I'm excited' beats 'I'm calm.'

buildup.text: Anxiety and excitement are nearly identical physiologically â€” racing heart, heightened alertness, adrenaline surge.

discovery.text: Trying to calm down fights your body's arousal state. Reframing the arousal as excitement works with it instead.

twist.text: In experiments, speakers who said 'I'm excited' before speaking were rated as more confident and persuasive.

climax.text: The reappraisal works because it changes the story you tell yourself, not the sensation you feel.

punchline.text: Same heartbeat. Different label. Better speech.

quiz.question: What did Alison Wood Brooks' research find?
options: Saying 'I'm excited' outperforms trying to calm down
